_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Program 1 Risk Management Plan

Ruby Pad

WPX Energy, Inc



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Recapture Solutions operates a portable refrigeration type gas dew point control and liquids recovery skid designed to recover propane, butane and natural gasoline from gas prior to gathering and final treatment for WPX Energy, Inc. (WPX) at the Ruby Pad.  This report provides the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the recovery skid system, pursuant to the requirements of the U.S. EPA RMP rule.



The system is designed to remove liquids from gas at the wellhead, having an inlet pressure between 150 and 400 psi.  The refrigeration system can operate at a chilling temperature as low as -40?F.  Recapture Solutions uses this system to remove liquids from flared gases.  The portability of the unit allows it to easily be moved from site to site when flaring ceases.  The PortaPack (LPG storage portable tank) is the only storage tank for liquid products, and has 18,000 gallons capacity. Recapture Solutions limits the maximum fill to 85% of the tank volume when the product temperature is above 0?F, 82% when the product temperature is below 0?F, or 80% when the product temperature is below -35?F. For the purpose of this assessment, the PortaPack is assumed to be completely filled to 85% of its total capacity (15,300 gallons), which is equivalent to 57,146 lbs. of flammable liquids.  



Under the authority of section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act, the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions require facilities that produce, handle, process, distribute, or store certain chemicals to develop a Risk Management Program, prepare a Risk Management Plan (RMP), and submit the RMP to EPA. Covered facilities were initially required to comply with the rule in 1999, and the rule has been amended on several occasions since then, most recently in 2004. This facility is regulated under Title 40, Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68), more commonly known as the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule. RMP

plans must be prepared for processes that store in excess of the thresholds set forth by 40 CFR 68.130. For flammable liquids, the threshold is 10,000 lbs.  Recapture Solutions can store approximately 57,146 lbs of LPG and exceeds 10,000 lbs. threshold, thus the facility is subject to the requirements of the Chemical Accident Prevention rule and must prepare a RMP.



LOCATION



Section 24, 149N, 94W, McKenzie County, North Dakota

Latitude: 47.703966, Longitude: -102.647251

From New Town, North Dakota go west 11.1 miles on ND-23 to ND-22.  Turn left and drive south on ND-22 for 8.5 miles to BIA Road 4.  Turn right onto BIA Road 4 and drive west for 1.0 mile and then turn left and go south for 1.0 mile. The Ruby Pad will be the first pad on your right.



DISPERSION MODELING ANALYSIS

The dispersion modeling analysis for accidental gas release into the ambient air is evaluated with the RMP*Comp program (Version 2.01). Besides the release and meteorological conditions discussed above, the analysis also utilized the rural ground surface roughness. The modeled Distance-To- Endpoint was 0.3 miles.



DISPERSION MODELING ANAYSIS WITH RMP*COMP



RMP*Comp: Results of Consequence Analysis

Scenario Summary

August 21, 2014

Chemical Name  CAS Number  Quantity Released (pounds)

Butane         106-97-8          14,286.5

Ethane         74-84-0           25,715.7

Propane        74-98-6           17,143.8



Threat type:      Flammable Gas

Scenario type:  Worst-case

Physical State: Liquefied under pressure

Release type:   Vapor Cloud Explosion

Estimated distance to 1 psi overpressure: 0.3 miles (0.5 kilometers)



OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS: POPULATION AND ENVIRONMENT



After the distance to the flammable endpoint has been determined, the offsite impacts on population, public receptors, and environmental receptors should be analyzed as required by the RMP rule. The population within a circle centered at the point of release and a radius equal to the distance to the

flammable endpoint should be estimated to two significant digits. In addition, all types of public receptors (schools, residences, hospitals, prisons, public recreation areas or arenas, major commercial or industrial areas) and environmental receptors (national or state parks, forests, or monuments; officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, or refuges; federal wilderness areas) within this distance should be identified.



A field survey was used to estimate the potentially affected population within the distance to the flammable endpoint and to identify public receptors.  The survey showed that no population is within the 0.3 mile impact radius for the worst case release. The impact area on a map is demonstrated in appendix A. The types of public receptors and environmental receptors identified within the impact area are listed in Table 2-2.  Google Earth was used to find the public receptors within the impact radius.  As can be seen from the impact area map, the distance to the nearest public receptor from the facility is approximately 0.3 miles, which is beyond the 0.2 mile distance to the level of concern. Additionally, no environmental receptors are impacted by the worst-case release scenario.
